launchData.description: SpaceX launched 23 Starlink satellites, including 13 with direct-to-cell capability, on a Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral.
launchData.article_summary: On April 27, 2025, SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral's SLC-40, carrying 23 Starlink satellites, 13 of which are capable of direct-to-cell phone service. Liftoff occurred at 10:09 p.m. EDT (0209 UTC). The booster, on its 20th flight, landed on the 'Just Read the Instructions' droneship after launch, and deployment of the satellites was confirmed about an hour later. This was SpaceX’s 48th Falcon 9 mission of 2025.

links.title: SpaceX launches 23 Starlink satellites on Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral

gptResponse.reasoning: The launch location in launchData is 'SLC-40, Cape Canaveral, Florida', which matches the candidate site 'SLC-40' at 'Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, Florida, USA'. The vehicle (Falcon 9) and operator (SpaceX) also match. Minor naming differences are normal, and this refers to the same physical pad.

launchData.location: Space Launch Complex 2 West (SLC-2W), Vandenberg Space Force Base, California
launchData.description: Firefly Aerospace Alpha rocket will launch the Lockheed Martin LM 400 Tech Demo satellite on the 'Message in a Booster' mission from SLC-2W, Vandenberg.
launchData.article_summary: Firefly Aerospace is set to launch its sixth Alpha rocket (FLTA006) carrying Lockheed Martin's LM 400 Technology Demonstration (Tech Demo) satellite on the 'Message in a Booster' mission. The launch, delayed for over a month due to weather and range restrictions, is now scheduled for April 28, 2025, with a window opening at 13:37 UTC from Space Launch Complex 2 West at Vandenberg Space Force Base. The mission is a technology demonstration for Lockheed Martin’s LM 400 satellite bus, part of a larger Lockheed contract for up to 25 Alpha launches. The LM 400 was encapsulated in March and will demonstrate its capabilities on a roughly 30-day low Earth orbit mission, after which it will perform a controlled de-orbit. The partnership between Firefly and Lockheed marks an expansion in rapid launch services for government and commercial customers. The article provides insight into the mission’s background, development, and operational goals, as well as range and weather challenges encountered in scheduling the launch.

launchData.location: SLC-2W, Vandenberg Space Force Base, California
launchData.payload: Lockheed Martin LM400 satellite bus (Message In A Booster)
launchData.description: Firefly Alpha FLTA006 launches the Lockheed Martin LM400 satellite bus on the Message In A Booster mission to polar orbit.
launchData.article_summary: Firefly Aerospace is set to launch its Alpha FLTA006 'Message In A Booster' mission from SLC-2W at Vandenberg Space Force Base, California, on April 28, 2025, at 13:37 UTC. The mission, a demonstration flight for Lockheed Martin, will place the LM400 satellite bus into polar orbit. The LM400 is designed as a multi-mission satellite platform for commercial, civil, and military uses, and this flight also marks the first of up to 25 missions in a multi-launch agreement between Firefly and Lockheed Martin. The LM400 on this mission is equipped with a communications payload and is intended to validate key capabilities of the bus. Firefly Alpha's four Reaver engines will power the rocket through ascent, and the LM400 will separate about 12 minutes after launch. This is the first Alpha flight of 2025, with more planned throughout the year. The article provides an overview of the LM400's design, production, and potential applications, along with details on Firefly's expanding launch infrastructure and future plans.

launchData.location: Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, Florida
launchData.description: Falcon 9 launched 23 Starlink satellites (including 13 direct-to-cell) from Cape Canaveral and landed its booster at sea.
launchData.article_summary: On April 27, 2025, SpaceX launched its 250th Starlink mission, sending 23 Starlink broadband satellites—including 13 with direct-to-cell capability—into low Earth orbit using a Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station. The launch marked the Falcon 9 booster's 20th flight, with a successful landing on the drone ship "Just Read the Instructions." This was SpaceX's 48th Falcon 9 launch of the year and the 31st dedicated to the Starlink constellation.

launchData.location: Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, Florida
launchData.description: Amazon's first batch of 27 Project Kuiper internet satellites launching on an Atlas V rocket.
launchData.article_summary: Amazon's first 27 Project Kuiper internet satellites, part of a broadband internet constellation, are scheduled to launch atop a ULA Atlas V rocket from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station on April 28. The mission, Kuiper 1, marks the first major deployment in Amazon's plan for a 3,200+ satellite constellation, following the launch of two prototypes in 2023. The launch was delayed from earlier April attempts due to weather and range availability issues. ULA has a two-hour launch window for the attempt.

launchData.description: SpaceX launch of NROL-145 classified spy satellites for the US National Reconnaissance Office.
launchData.article_summary: On April 20, 2025, SpaceX launched the 10th batch of 'proliferated architecture' spy satellites for the US National Reconnaissance Office (NRO), with the mission named NROL-145. The Falcon 9 rocket lifted off from Vandenberg Space Force Base in California at 8:29 a.m. EDT. This series of launches supports the NRO's new network of many small, cost-effective satellites, believed to be modified Starlink spacecraft equipped with advanced reconnaissance technology. As is typical for NRO missions, specific payload details remain classified. The Falcon 9's first stage successfully landed on a drone ship in the Pacific Ocean, marking its 12th launch and landing. The webcast ended after booster landing at the NRO's request, and no further payload information was released.

SLC-4E is the known Falcon 9 pad at Vandenberg and matches the vehicle/operator in this launch. SLC-2 is operated by Firefly Aerospace and used for different rockets.
